title: Is divorce in California biased against men?
question: I have been researching divorce attorneys for several months now. Sometimes, I feel that because I am a guy, and the primary bread winner, I am at a tremendous disadvantage. It's like the other party will be winning the lottery. Once property division, alimony, and child support are decided, the other party will walk away with a large sum of money, leaving the other party in debt. Meanwhile, who knows what the other party will do with their newly found fortune? I find it completely unfair to have to support a person that never wanted to work a day in their life. I can understand child support, but spousal support of more than one year duration; really? Any law changes in the near future? Will the advent of gay marriage affect how divorce , support and division of assets are handled?
answers:
The law is supposed to be gender blind. Because you're the primary bread winner, you may very well have to pay spousal support, but that's not because you're a guy. A woman who is the primary earner can certainly end up paying spousal support to her husband. But there are a number of factors that the judge must consider in setting spousal support. The judge must balance all of those factors using his/her reasonable discretion.

As for gay marriage, theoretically it should be handled the same as a marriage between a man and a woman.

This is true of women who are the primary bread winners as well. I agree it does not seem fair but the law is not bias against men. It is no fault and regardless of the gender, the primary wage earner, even if the other spouse or partner never worked, is entitled to support until he or she can become self supporting.

Researching family law attorneys is a good idea. I suggest you schedule consultations with 2 or 3 attorneys to find the one you feel most comfortable with. Most attorneys offer an initial consultation for a minimal fee or for free.
No the law is not biased against the man. However, it may seem that way when the husband is the higher earner and has been throughout the marriage. But courts will also order the Wife to pay spousal support when the situation is reversed. If you had a long term marriage, your wife did not work and stayed at home caring for the children, her earning capacity as a result is likely greatly diminished.
A good family law attorney may be able to help you minimize the amount and duration of support based on the facts of your case.
The solution is to be sure you know who you are marrying--and have a prenup. Not laws.

Mr. Benton has provided excellent counsel. While varying jurisdictions have their own standards for determining how its done, most jurisdictions focus on the division of assets in a marriage. The underlying basis is what is an equitable distribution of the marital assets. Unfortunately, many marriages are not composed of partners who earn, or have the capacity to earn, equally. As a result, it will often seem that one party is benefiting from a divorce and the other is being punished.

Interesting question. But no it doesn't advantage anyone. I don't know the sources you are looking at but I question their validity. As to gay marriage, it is handled like any other divorce. You need to talk to a family law attorney. As to child support, the law holds both parents to a moral standard of insuring that the children of the marriage are properly cared for and provided. As to spousal support, it is the public policy that a supported party at some point become self supporting and that time frame depends on the length of the marriage. As to property, why shouldn't a spouse who has been a care provided not share equally in the community assets and debts?
